input: Write a short biography of Bill Nye.
output: Isaac William Newkirk "Bill" Nye (born 1955) is an American author, science communicator and television personality. In 1977, Nye became the host of the children's television show _"Bill Nye the Science Guy,"_ which aired for four years. He has since become a vocal advocate for science and publicly opposed President Donald Trump's denial of climate change. In a 2011 cover story, _Scientific American_ named Nye to their list of the "50 Most Influential Scientists in the World."

input: Write a short biography of Bill Nye.
output: William Sanford "Bill" Nye (born 1955) is an American scientist, educator, and TV personality. He wrote a book about climate change in 2016. Nye became a household name as the host for Bill Nye the Science Guy, which launched in 1993 and ran until 1998. He also starred in the reality show Bill Nye Saves the World, which debuted in 2017 and ran until 2020. The National Science Foundation called Bill Nye's television program “one of the most significant influences on students’ minds about science in the past twenty years.” Nye founded the Planetary Society in 1980 to "foster the exploration of space."

input: Write a short biography of Bill Nye.
output: William Sanford "Bill" Nye (born 1955) is an American science communicator, television personality, and mechanical engineer. Known as "The Science Guy," he hosted the Emmy Award-winning PBS show Bill Nye the Science Guy from 1993-98. Nye worked at Boeing before turning to educating the public. He founded The Planetary Society in 1980 as a nonprofit advocate for space exploration. Nye later worked for Disney, the American Museum of Natural History, and Columbia University. Elected to the Smithsonian Institution's National Advisory Board, he has written many books.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100?-44 BCE) was among the most important political leaders in Roman history and a major figure in the expansion of Roman territory and culture. A Roman general, Caesar became one of the three most powerful men of the Roman Republic, leading the republican faction of the First Triumvirate. Caesar began his career as a military tribune under his uncle, who was governor of Sallentinis and Celtice provinces. As a young man, he became an accomplished military commander. At 30 years of age, Caesar defeated Pharnaces and his army in a bloody battle in 89 BCE. In 87 BCE, he crossed the Rubicon, and later led the Battle of Pharsalus and the final decisive Battles of Thapsus, where his forces slaughtered their Numidian opponents. Caesar came to power after the civil war on 46 BCE ended with Caesar's victory at the battle of Munda. Caesar made peace with Mark Anthony and Marcus Licinius Crassus, but was assassinated by a conspiracy led by Gaius Cassius and Marcus Junius Brutus

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman military and political leader who conquered Britain, created what became Italy and launched the first Roman invasion of Germany. His conquests came after years of fighting for the Roman aristocracy, and he ascended to consul in 59 BCE. Caesar was assassinated in 44 BCE, just a month after he crossed the Rubicon river and began civil war. He was succeeded by his adopted nephew Octavian, who would become Augustus, the first Roman emperor.

output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BC) was a politician and general who served as Consul multiple times. Growing up in a prominent family, Caesar served in the army and led his first military campaign at age 17. As a young man, he was exiled for his opposition to aristocratic rule, but he returned to make a name for himself. input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100 BC-44 BC) was a Roman general and statesman who went from military hero to dictator. Rising through the ranks of the Roman Republic, after his service in Gaul, Caesar led a successful invasion of Egypt and served as governor. Returning to Rome, he was appointed head of the senate and executed his famous "coup," putting an end to the Roman Republic and becoming Dictator for life. He ruled until assassinated in 44 BC. Caesar's popularity among common Romans made his assassination highly controversial. The subsequent civil war between his opponents and his sons was ended by the triumvirate of Gaius Octavian, Marcus Antonius, and Marcus Lepidus, who created the Roman Empire.

input: Write a short biography of The Rolling Stones.
output: The Rolling Stones are one of Britain's best-loved groups. Founded in London in 1962, Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, Brian Jones, Charlie Watts, and Ronnie Wood became members at different times. Originally part of a 1960s counterculture movement, the group embodied Swinging London and released a string of hits, including "(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction," "Angie," "Paint It Black," and "(I Can't Get No) Strippin' Blues." After the 1971 death of Brian Jones, Keith Richard was arrested for heroin possession and the band was on the verge of a breakup until they were released early and went on a 1970s renaissance. The Stones performed their first American concert at the Altamont Free Concert, a violent and widely-mocked event. In the late 21st century, Mick Jagger and Keith Richards continued to tour as lead guitarist Ronnie Wood was forced to retire.

Members Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, Brian Jones, Ian Stewart and Charlie Watts were childhood friends who became a popular blues band on the UK and US club scene in the early 1960s. They later emerged as pioneers of the British beat and rock scene in 1963. They wrote some of rock's greatest hits, including "Satisfaction," "Sympathy for the Devil" and "Paint It Black." They have released 25 studio albums, 22 live albums and 143 singles, including 23 top 10s and five US #1s.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is a British primatologist and conservationist who is known for her research on chimpanzees in Tanzania. She learned sign language to communicate with chimpanzees, and in 1962 became the first person to observe chimpanzees making tools. She's written twenty books on animal behavior, and founded the Jane Goodall Institute, which works to protect chimpanzees, other animal species and the environment. She's received numerous awards for her work, including the J. Paul Getty Wildlife Conservation Prize and the United Nations' Messenger of Peace.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is a British primatologist and ethologist known for her work with chimpanzees. She began studying at Cambridge in the 1950s before travelling to Africa to live among the wild animals she had read about in her childhood. Goodall established the Gombe Chimpanzee Research Project in 1960 in what is now Tanzania, where she lived and worked among the animals until her departure in 1975. A world-renowned expert on chimpanzees, she authored numerous books and was named a senior fellow of Dame of Great Britain at Queen Elizabeth II's Jubilee in 2002.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is a British primatologist and ethologist whose book "In the Shadow of Man" is considered a classic of naturalist writing. She has spent more than six decades working with and observing chimpanzees in their native habitat, gaining a unique understanding of their intelligence and social behaviors. She was named a United Nations Messenger of Peace in 2002 and earned the National Geographic Society's Hubbard Medal in 2003. Goodall has published 40 books and received more than 60 honorary degrees. Her Roots & Shoots Foundation focuses on youth development and environmental education.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is a British primatologist who is widely considered one of the world's leading authorities on chimpanzees. As a young zookeeper in London, she observed chimpanzees and dreamed of traveling to Africa to study them in their natural habitat. She traveled to Gombe Stream National Park in Tanzania in 1960. There, she set up an observation camp and lived among the wild chimps. Goodall's research led her to discover behavior such as the use of tools, warfare, and infanticide. In 1977, she founded the Jane Goodall Institute to promote the conservation of wildlife and its habitats around the world. In 2002, she was awarded a U.S. Presidential Medal.

input: Write a short biography of David Gilmour.
output: David Gilmour (born 1946) is the lead vocalist and guitarist for the rock group Pink Floyd. Formed in 1965, Pink Floyd is known for pioneering progressive rock with albums such as "The Dark Side of the Moon" (1973) and "Wish You Were Here" (1975). Gilmour sang lead on many of their songs, including the U.S. Top 20 hits, "Money," "Wish You Were Here," "Another Brick in the Wall (Part 2)," and "Comfortably Numb." With Floyd, he has sold over 120 million albums and won two Grammy Awards for "The Dark Side of the Moon" and "Best Boxed or Special Limited Edition Package." After more than 50 years together, Pink Floyd announced its retirement in 2014, though they reunited three years later at a charity concert. Gilmour continues to sell out solo shows, playing songs by Pink Floyd along with an autobiographical one hour performance.

input: Write a short biography of Oprah Winfrey.
output: Oprah Winfrey (born 1954) is an American media proprietor, talk show host, actress and philanthropist. Born into poverty to an unmarried mother, Oprah was raised by her aunt and uncle in a predominantly white neighborhood in Tennessee before relocating to Chicago where she began a broadcasting career. She founded the Oprah Winfrey Show in 1986 and became America's richest media personality in 2004. She used her influence to become a social reformer, focusing on poverty, education and the #MeToo movement for women. Her network, OWN, produces a large slate of shows including Weight Watchers, the final season of Jane Fonda: Workout with Jane Fonda, as well as The Book Club, starring Oprah, Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra VII (69 BCE-30 BCE) was the last pharaoh of Ancient Egypt. She reigned from 51 BCE-30 BCE alongside her father, Ptolemy XII, and her brother, Ptolemy XIII. A powerful ruler, she is known for her beauty, wit, and military prowess. The Roman general, Julius Caesar, took a romantic interest in her and formed a political alliance. She married his son, Ptolemy XIV, and bore his son, Caesarion. She later married Roman general Mark Antony, who had been an enemy of her brother. Despite the popular image of Cleopatra as a power-hungry villain, she made decisions based on military advantage and her dynasty's survival.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (around 69-30 BCE) was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Empire, a dynasty that began as a Greek colony in Egypt but later adopted Egyptian traditions like worship of the local gods. Cleopatra rose to power in 51 BCE, ruling through her brother-husband Ptolemy XIII. After Ptolemy's death, she and Ptolemy's widow ruled as joint sovereigns, before Cleopatra was forced to give up the throne. Later, she became the ruler of Alexandria and Ptolemy Auletes' daughter and eventual heir. The Romans invaded Egypt in 30 BCE. Cleopatra committed suicide by poisoning, but her death did not halt the Roman conquest of Egypt.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69-30 BC), the last Pharaoh of Egypt, ruled for 22 years. She worked with Roman leader Julius Caesar to quell Egypt's Ptolemaic dynasty. input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69-30 BCE) was a major figure in the Ptolemaic Dynasty in Egypt. She became Queen of Egypt upon the death of her husband, Ptolemy XI. He was assassinated by her brother, Ptolemy XII, so she fled with her son Caesarion to Syria, where she married her second husband, Mark Antony, and bore him twins. She became a pawn in the Roman Civil War and, after Antony's death, she was forced to kill herself with poison.

input: Write a short biography of The Weeknd.
output: Abel Tesfaye (born 1990), known by his stage name "The Weeknd", is a Canadian singer, songwriter, and record producer. Born and raised in Scarborough, Ontario, Tesfaye started his music career in 2010, releasing his debut project, an EP called "House of Balloons," anonymously. His debut album, "Trilogy", was released in 2012, and his second album, "Kiss Land", came out the following year. He achieved large mainstream success with the 2015 album "Beauty Behind the Madness." His third album, Starboy, was released in 2016, with singles "Starboy" and "The Hills" becoming worldwide mega-hits, and he has followed that up with the album "Chapter III" (2019) and its top singles "Heartless" and "Blinding Lights" featuring Coldplay.

input: Write a short biography of The Weeknd.
output: The Weeknd, also known as Abel Tesfaye, is a Canadian singer and songwriter. He grew up in Scarborough, Ontario. As a teenager, he began releasing a series of low-budget mixtapes on the Internet. He signed to Universal and XO and was discovered by legendary producer-songwriter-label executive Rick Rubin. In 2011, he released “House of Balloons/Glass Table Girls/The Morning,” which made #34 on the Billboard chart. His 2012 album “Trilogy” also made the chart. “Echoes of Silence” made #21 with over a million units sold. The Weeknd signed to the XO label with Republic, releasing the single “Often.” He released his major-label album “Kiss Land” that year, making the #5 spot on the chart. He dropped his third studio album “Beauty Behind The Madness” and won a Grammy for Album Of The Year in 2015.

input: Write a short biography of The Weeknd.
output: The Weeknd (Ahmad Abadullahee, born 1990), commonly known simply as The Weeknd, is a Canadian singer and songwriter known for his emotional, sometimes gloomy R&B style. His 2012 breakthrough smash hit "Earned It" off the Fifty Shades of Grey tracklist propelled him into stardom and won Grammy and Academy Awards. He followed that with a hit album, Beauty Behind the Madness (2015). He is known for sultry vocals, sometimes moody or even dark-sounding songs, often featuring sex, drugs, love lost and loneliness. He also plays piano and keyboard and produces all his songs. Critics praise his emotional depth and expressiveness but criticize his reliance on autotune and "faux-haziness."

input: Write a short biography of The Weeknd.
output: The Weeknd (born Abel Tesfaye in 1990) is a Canadian singer-songwriter and producer known for his melancholic R&B tracks. He grew up in Toronto, attending a church and studying classical piano, before moving to Montreal in 2011 for school. Tesfaye began posting music on YouTube and SoundCloud, later releasing his debut studio album, _Kiss Land_, in 2013. His follow-up, _Beauty Behind the Madness_ (2015), became one of the best-selling albums of that year. _Starboy_ (2016) cemented his fame, reaching number one in the US charts. More albums and tours followed, and he appeared on various hit tracks. Some of his songs, such as "Call out My Name," have sparked controversy, but he continues to be an influential figure in contemporary R&B and pop.

input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.

After receiving her graduate degree in biological sciences in Britain, Maathai returned to Kenya to study the effects of soil erosion and deforestation. Founding the Green Belt Movement, she organized female groups to plant trees and advocate for sustainability, winning the 2004 Nobel Peace Prize. She continued campaigning for female representation in government, becoming the first female Deputy Speaker of  Parliament in 1992.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (born 1934) is an Israeli-American psychologist and winner of the 2002 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences. He studied how decision making, memory and cognition are influenced by cognitive bias. In collaboration with Amos Tversky, Kahneman developed prospect theory, which challenges the "rational" assumption that risks are equally preferred. They also proved that people make systematic errors in their decision-making, focusing on the present instead of the long-term or the average. Kahneman was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2013 as well as the National Humanities Medal in 2019.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.

A professor of psychology and public affairs at Princeton University, he made extensive contributions to the field of behavioral economics, studying how economic decisions are shaped by human biases. input: Write a short biography of Mark Twain.
output: Mark Twain (1835-1910) was a 19th-century American writer, journalist, and humorist. He helped establish his country's most widely read publication: The Atlantic. Twain wrote about humanity and satire in such works as _The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County_. His most famous work was perhaps _The Adventures of Tom Sawyer_ (1876), with its portrayal of a rebellious young boy. Twain is noted for his satirical works, such as _Life on the Mississippi_ (1883), which made fun of his hometown, Hannibal, Missouri. His books remain popular today, especially _The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn_ (1885), which was banned for language. Twain lived long enough to see his country go to war with itself in the Civil War, which was his inspiration for his most successful book, the satire _Adventures of Huckleberry Finn_ (1885). Throughout his life, Twain became one of the most famous American authors in literature.

output: Mark Twain (1835-1910) was an American writer, journalist, satirist, and humorist. After marrying in 1853, he became a mining inspector in San Francisco in gold country. input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.
output: Rosa Parks (1913-2005) was an African American civil rights activist. Parks was active in the NAACP and worked as a secretary. In 1955, Parks refused to leave her seat on a segregated bus in Montgomery, Alabama. Her protest sparked the 1955 Montgomery Bus Boycott and helped mobilize African Americans across the South. Arrested on December 1, 1955, she was later convicted and fined. The US Supreme Court eventually overturned her conviction. In 1957, she joined the NAACP's legal team and worked as an investigator. Parks spent the last years of her life advocating for women's suffrage and other social justice causes.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.
output: Rosa Parks (1913-2005) was an African American civil-rights activist and one of the founders of the American Civil Rights Movement. She refused to give up her seat to a white man on a public bus in Montgomery, Alabama, prompting a year-long campaign of bus boycotts which eventually ended segregation on buses in Alabama. Parks was the first inductee into the U.S. Civil Rights Memorial. Named America's greatest black person in January 2002, Parks was honored with the U.S. Congressional Gold Medal in 1999 and the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1996.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.
output: Rosa Louise Parks (1913-2005) was a civil rights activist who became an icon of the American civil rights movement with her refusal to give up her bus seat to a white man in 1955. The act of resistance sparked the Montgomery Bus Boycott and became a symbol of the movement. Parks devoted her life to fighting segregation. She was active in the NAACP, the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, the National Council of Negro Women and a number of other groups. In 1996, the Rosa and Raymond Parks Institute was established in her honor. She posthumously received the Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Barack Obama.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.

After refusing to give up her seat on a bus to a white man, Parks became a leading figure in the Montgomery bus boycott. Her civil disobedience played a key role in the success of the movement, eventually leading to the desegregation of the city's bus system. input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.

The African American seamstress refused to relinquish her seat to a white passenger on a bus in Montgomery, Alabama, prompting a boycott. input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.
output: Rosa Parks (1913-2005) was an activist and civil rights pioneer. She rose to national prominence in 1955 when she refused to give up her seat on a bus to a white passenger, an act of defiance that sparked the Montgomery bus boycott. Parks was eventually arrested and fined, in one of many incidents of racial harassment she suffered during her life. She became an organizer with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and participated in the historic 1963 March on Washington. Parks continued to fight for civil rights and became widely revered for her work. She was honored with a posthumous Presidential Medal of Freedom.

input: Write a short biography of Anne Frank.
output: Anne Frank (1929-1945) was a German-Dutch Jewish diarist who wrote The Diary of a Young Girl. Born in Germany, she and her family fled to the Netherlands in 1933 to escape Nazi persecution. Her family hid in Nazi occupied Amsterdam during the Second World War and survived for nearly two years, but were eventually discovered and sent to concentration camps. Frank died in 1945 of typhus, while in captivity in Germany. After the war, Otto Frank, and Miep Gies rescued his daughter's diary from the rubble and published it. It has been translated into nearly 100 languages. The family's efforts to survive their harsh conditions were later adapted into Frank’s memoir, The Secret Annexe. Frank’s diary has been praised for its moving descriptions and lasting impact, both personally and as a window into Nazi Germany.

input: Write a short biography of Anne Frank.
output: Anne Frank (1929-1944) is one of the most famous victims of the Holocaust. At the age of 13, she and her family fled the Nazis and moved into the Secret Annex, a set of rooms behind Otto Frank's office. Anne kept a diary during the family's two years in hiding, describing her daily life in the Annex. In August 1944, she was deported to Auschwitz-Birkenau where she died of typhus. Her diary was later discovered and published. The first postwar edition was published in 1947, and has been translated into over 50 languages.

Her diary, which details her fears, hopes, and growing awareness of the war, was published after her death. Anne Frank and her family were arrested in 1944 and deported to a concentration camp in 1945, shortly before their liberation. Her diary, published posthumously in 1947, has become a classic of Holocaust survivor literature and one of the most popular books in history.

input: Write a short biography of Anne Frank.
output: Anneliese Marie "Anne" Frank (1929-1945) was a German-Dutch diarist whose The Diary of a Young Girl (1947) has been translated into more than 60 languages. Frank, her family, and four other Jews hid from the Nazis in an Amsterdam office from 1942-44. Frank's father Otto Frank discovered the journal after their arrest and the journal was published. input: Write a short biography of Anne Frank.
output: Anne Frank (1929-1945) was a German Jewish child holocaust victim best known for her account of her family's wartime in hiding, The Diary of a Young Girl. Frank and her family lived in German-occupied Amsterdam during World War II. After Jews were forced into a walled-off section of the city, Frank and her family went into hiding with four others in a secret room in the attic of a house. The group, including Frank's parents and sister, were eventually captured and found guilty of being partisans. Anne, her sister, and mother were sent to the Nazi concentration camps at Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, where they died in mid-1945, three months before German surrender. Frank's father was the one the Dutch found, who died of typhus in a prison camp shortly after his liberation. Frank's diary, published in 1947, became popular, prompting many film and book adaptations. Frank and the others were honored posthumously by Yad Vashem as "Righteous Among the Nations".

input: Write a short biography of Audre Lorde.
output: Audre Lorde (1934-1992) was a womanist writer, feminist theorist, and civil rights activist. She published works of poetry, memoir, and criticism that addressed racism, sexism, and lesbian identity in the United States. Growing up in Harlem, she began writing poetry in the 1950s. At the same time she was a leading practitioner of the black-power movement. In 1973, after moving to Staten Island, she was diagnosed with breast cancer. Her poetry dealt with the experience as well as broader themes of oppression. In the 1980s she received critical acclaim after the publication of her groundbreaking works of both poetry and prose. Lorde's work has influenced contemporary women of color feminism and the black rights movements.

input: Write a short biography of Amelia Earhart.
output: Amelia Earhart (1897-1937) was an American aviator whose disappearance over the Pacific in 1937 became one of the greatest mysteries of the 20th century. As a child, she was fascinated by stories of women adventurers like Nellie Bly and Elizabeth Bisland. After making history as the first woman to cross the Atlantic alone in 1928, Earhart set several air speed records before retiring from aviation. She became a spokesperson for women's rights and the Equal Rights Amendment, and a tireless advocate for social justice. Earhart's plan to circle the world was thwarted by ill health and financial difficulties. At the end of her life, Earhart was struggling to pay bills and establish her identity as an author. She is frequently cited as one of the most famous Americans in history and remains an icon of feminism and female empowerment. Despite never finding her plane, many believe Earhart survived capture and later died a Japanese prisoner of war.

input: Write a short biography of Bryan Stevenson.
output: Bryan Stevenson (born 1959) is a black human rights lawyer who served as executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative from 1989 to 2014. He made his professional screen debut in 2014's Interstellar and gained acclaim the following year for his lead role in Call Me by Your Name. His role in Beautiful Boy, opposite Steve Carell, earned him a Golden Globe Award nomination. The actor is known for taking on diverse roles, which have included playing Bob Dylan in a biopic and leading a production of King Lear.

input: Write a short biography of Halle Berry.
output: Halle Berry (born 1966) is an American actress and model. A pioneering African-American actress, Berry was the first woman of color to win an Academy Award for Best Actress. Berry was discovered as a model in Chicago and earned minor roles in television movies and video games before landing her breakthrough part in the 1992 romantic comedy Strictly Business. She won the Best Actress Oscar for 2001's Monster's Ball. Berry starred in the James Bond film Die Another Day (2002), the X-Men series (2000-2017), the crime comedy The Call (2013), and the HBO film Kings (2014). As a fashion model, Berry posed for a French edition of Playboy in 1989. Berry has been married three times and has appeared in dozens of film and television roles. Since 1990, she has also advocated on women's health issues and has been a national spokeswoman for Revlon cosmetics.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1871-1919) was a German-Polish philosopher, political activist, and socialist. She worked at an agricultural school in Poland and was inspired to become a socialist after reading Karl Marx. Luxemburg supported the October Revolution in Russia and fought on the Russian front in World War I, eventually becoming a pacifist. She fled to Poland and to exile in 1917 during a crackdown on socialists in Germany. A radical reformer, she worked with Karl Liebknecht to oppose the imperialist war. Luxemburg was arrested, brought back to Germany and executed.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1870-1919) was a socialist philosopher and economist. She came from a Polish Jewish intellectual family and moved to Germany in 1887. Luxemburg joined the Social Democratic Party in 1890. Opposed to World War I and support for war, Luxemburg formed the Communist Party of Germany that merged with the Spartacist League. She and Karl Liebknecht founded the German Communist Party in 1918, but the short-lived government was quickly crushed by the government. She was murdered a few weeks later in a German prison.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1870-1919) was a German socialist and critic of World War I. She studied economics and philosophy before joining the Social Democratic Party, later founding the Social Democracy of the Kingdom of Poland. After moving to Berlin, Luxemburg organized strikes and helped form the Spartacus League and Left Social Democratic Party, becoming a leading voice for anti-war protest. Luxemburg was jailed during World War I and fled to Switzerland before the war ended. After returning to Germany, she was arrested and killed on January 15, 1919.

output: Bob Marley (1945-1981) was a Jamaican reggae legend and human rights advocate. The father of seven children and leader of the Wailers, Marley was a pioneer of reggae music as well as Jamaican conscious Rastafari movement. input: Write a short biography of Bob Marley.
output: Robert Nesta "Bob" Marley (1945-1981) was a Jamaican singer-songwriter and musician known for popularizing reggae worldwide in the 1970s. Inspired in his youth by American acts like Little Richard and Aretha Franklin, Bob began performing and recording on his own. After a series of albums in Jamaica and England, Bob joined a group called the "Wailers" in 1963. They made several top-notch albums and singles for Island Records until 1976. Bob then began a solo career, creating critically lauded albums like "Lively Up Yourself" (1976) and "Exodus" (1977) as well as popular live work and singles. His 1977 world tour helped bring reggae to a global audience, including many white US fans and musicians. In 1981, Bob died of melanoma at age 36. His songs and legacy endure today.

output: Robert Nesta "Bob" Marley (1945-1981) achieved global fame for his work with the reggae band the Wailers, his solo career, and as a philanthropist. Marley was born in Jamaica to a family of poor farmers; he took up singing as a teenager. input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1870-1919) was a Polish-German philosopher and Marxist revolutionary. She was a founder of the Social Democratic Party of Germany as well as the Spartacists and author of several works on political and social theory. input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1871-1919) was a Polish-German Marxist theorist known for advocating socialism rather than reformism and revolution. Born in Poland to a Jewish family, she moved to Berlin in 1889 and joined the Social Democratic Party. After the formation of the Spartacist League, she fought alongside Karl Liebknecht in the German Revolution of 1919. She was arrested by the Freikorps, shot and incarcerated in 1919. She was released in 1920, but imprisoned again in 1921. In 1922, Luxemburg and other Spartacists, including Liebknecht, were murdered by Freikorps troops at the behest of Berlin police.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.

She became a Marxist and supported Vladimir Lenin's Bolshevik faction in Russia. Her writings helped build popular support for socialism in Germany, where she helped establish the Social Democratic Party in 1905. She was arrested in 1916 as a "public enemy." In captivity, she was tortured and then shot by right-wing paramilitaries.
